comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] Do you know when the Paragon Hotel western extension happened? It is six windows wide in this photo, but three in earlier ones, eg investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... . Also the Ship Inn at the corner of Pitt and Alfred Streets?

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Isn't the Paragon Hotel right across the street from the customs house ?   The building you labelled looks to far away.

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] that's definitely the Paragon it was originally only on the corner of Alfred and Loftus as per this image from SRNSW investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... but was later extended and fronted Loftus, Alfred and Arbitration Streets as can be seen in this 1913 image from SLNSW: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=53194 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The extension was almost certainly finished by 1910 as the copy of the map I have from that year shows it fronting all three streets. Looking at Trove this may have happened in 1909/10 as there is indication of a contract issued for alterations and additions in September 1909 and in SMH of 11 Jan 1910 it says: 'Extensive alterations have been carried out to the Paragon Hotel, the interior having been completely transformed. The work was carried out by Messrs. D. Gawne and Sons, from plans under the supervision of Messrs. Morrow and De Putron, architects.' But of course they may have happened earlier than this - I just haven't found any evidence yet :-) Incidently the pub was first built in 1860 for Anthony Hordern and was run by the Watsons from the 1860s to 1933 when it was bought by Tooth & Co. The 'new' Ship Inn on the corner of Pitt and Alfred was built in 1902 replacing the original which was across the street and established in c1868. The original was demolished when Alfred Street was widened and the licencee moved to the new pub. The original site is basically in the the middle of Alfred Street. Interestingly looking at both their websites you would never know any of this as it's obviously not worth mentioning the 'ancient' history of trendy gastro pubs. So far then this definitely fits with your 1905-1910 date range as it's hard to know when the additions were in fact carried out but we might be talking c1909/10 Also you might like this c1879-1887 image of the paragon! www.slv.vic.gov.au/pictoria/gid/slv-pic-aab70439/1/b28130 right, i'll shut up now

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] Don't ever shut up! That is a wonderful amount of quality information. I hope you enjoyed researching it. I am always amazed that the Paragon has survived numerous Circular Quay rebuilds for 150+ years. Here is another very early photo of the Hotel (1868) - www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/5760146474/ . Tweddle's Belmore Hotel (see note) aka "The First and Last" was rebuilt in 1911 ( trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15207874 ). Old building apparent in this photo, so that might be the latest date. Tram expert required for this - I think the central tramway pylons were replaced c.1908 for side posts, as evidenced here in front of the Ship Inn (to allow for wider-bodied tram cars). Which again points nearer 1910.

comment._content: the manly ferry to the left and the small paddle wheeler to the right could go a long way to an accurate date,sorry but my ferry info got lost, the ferries of sydney  by grahame andrews has good info and you could possible get an exact date

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/terrycrowley] Thanks for the reminder! I just happen to have beside me a copy of the book by Graeme Andrews "A Pictorial History of Ferries Sydney and surrounding waterways" (Reed, 1982). On page 32 is a photo taken from exactly this position, and possibly minutes away in time, like the Kerry photos above. I wish I could see the clocks! Buildings and adverts are identical (but cropped out from the RH side of the Lands Department Building). There are more ferries in his photo, and he identifies each of them. The 'Kuring-Gai' at the Manly wharf, and the 'Bronzewing' are also in this photo (see notes). Graeme Andrews says in his blurb that "World War One is a year or so away ..." ie.c.1912. BUT he also describes the 'First and Last' Hotel as being pulled down in 1981, when in fact it was the 1911 rebuild which was destroyed then. (See dunedoo's excellent and poignant series ot the 'new' hotel's 1981 demolition - www.flickr.com/photos/29029178@N03/4655952814/ .) The Hotel was mentioned as about to undergo alterations in September 1910 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15207874 . Somewhere I found an article saying it was an empty site in 1911, implying that this photo (and the one in the Andrews book, and the Kerry photos) are all 1910. (Found it - 3rd last on page - www.gdaypubs.com.au/NSW/sydney/city.html )

comment.author: 75983496@N00
comment._content: yess,the bronzewing, I have an idea from memory that it sank?but correct me if Im wrong, I have'nt seen GA's books for 20years

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/terrycrowley] 'Bronzewing' built 1899, 500 passengers, 12+ knots, short funnel to get under river bridges so smoke billowed over upper deck passengers (!), broken up c.1931 (from the Andrews book).

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Here is the 'sister' photo which is in the Andrews book - sitting under our noses in State Records NSW Archive ever surprising Series 4481 !! Some of the ferries are identified in the title (not 'Bronzewing'), and the date is "earlier than 1916" - Spot the differences!
